/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I don't quite understand how this may happen?

Why not to override default tempest_test_default_includelist and explicitly define set of tests you want to run instead of placing super simmilar excludelist?

Ie we're including all magnum tests except some specific ones:
https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/src/branch/master/tests/roles/bootstrap-host/templates/user_variables_magnum.yml.j2#L54-L64

An example, some jobs we are running only tempest.scenario.TestBasicNetworkScenario that contains like 3 tests, and these tests are failing due some known bug. We add it in our skiplist [1]. So, at the end, all tests under TestBasicNetworkScenario are being skipped, and our jobs are failing because of that. We can't afford to run more than a few tests on check and gate because of the time/resources consuming.

1 - https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-tempest-skiplist/src/branch/master/roles/validate-tempest/vars/tempest_skip.yml

Well, IMO, but that would be a valid CI failure, because you don't actually run relevant tests.
So instead of doing smth with test results or define another set of tests explicitly, you're suggesting to run fake one and even not knowing that you're not running anything useful?

an alternative would be to unconditionally add the keystone tests to the list of included tests supplied to this role? Seems like a lot of code and some duplication is introduced here to patch over an unusual set of input.

defaults/main.yml.message: another simpler approach might be to define a new variable `tempest_test_default_tests: "keystone_tempest_plugin.tests.api"` and concatenate it with tempest_test_default_includelist at this point, then no extra logic would be required in the tasks and it would be possible to disable that behaviour by overriding tempest_test_default_tests as an empty list if necessary.
I do tend to agree with with dimitry though that this patch really does seem to be addressing the symptom of weird/broken input data rather than addressing the root cause

right so none of the host cpu tread sibling pairing was ever approved or allowed by the specs that intoduced cpu pinning and since the code im removing updated the cpu toptolgy in the numa toplogy not the one we used to generate the xml in inst.vcpu_model.topology i dont see how this could have ever had a practical impact on the guests.

this was for better or worse dead code from the point of view of generating the xml and incorrect code form the point of view of selecting a host. it is incorrect to consider the host cpu toplogy when generating the guest cpu topology. we have inccorectly in my view for example made some asstiontion with regard to the require policy but that is a different matter.

nothing we have ever stated with regard to cpu topoology has ever stated we woudl map guest hypertread to host hypertreads. if you want to have 4 threads per core on a host with only 1 thread per core that is fine as is having a guest with 1 thread per core on a host with 2.

the only things we have ever said is if you have a virtual numa node toplogy you can map the virtual cpus to a virtual numa node.

we have a unriten rule tha the libvirt driver that each virtual numa node will be mapped to a different host numa node. that is not guarenteed by the api and hyperv does not have to do the same if they done want too but there is nothign that says guest thread pairs will be mapped to host thread pairs.

anyway i dont think this is a regression and i dont think its reasonable for anyone to rely on it today.

ah i read your comment ya so the previus behavior with cpu pinning was definitely a bug then.
it was in apporparte to alter the guest cpu toplogy based on the host cpu toplogy when using cpu pinning
as that produces a tight coupleing that may limit its live migration capablity. 

i can see why you would want to do this and i even suggested doing something very similar in the past where i wanted to change the best fit cpu toplogy to slect the toplogy that matched the host toplogy most closely which si effectivly what the code was trying to do but the different is that it was elimitaning possable combination instead of weighting the different topologies.

what is incorrect is not the optimisation but rather that it would limit the set of possible topologies.
filtering is not correct here so _filter_for_numa_threads shoudl be removed but sorting the topologies
this should have been implemented as part of _score_cpu_topology or _sort_possible_cpu_topologies

what i was previously proposing indepent of this was altering _sort_possible_cpu_topologies to compute the cpu toplogy with the smallest delta form the hosts.  you can do that genericaly by trating the atibutes of the topolgoy as corrdinates in a vector spaces. e.g. (socket, core, thread)  are like (x,y,z) points in a 3 dimtional space and you select the topoligy that is the shotest distance form the host toplogy.

That should give you the optimal toplogy in most cases. i can look at implementign that if you would like.
it will do the optimisation correctly for both pinned and unpinned instances.

I don't think you've diagnosed this correctly. My understanding of this code is that it allows us to best map the host topology to the guest topology. Consider a 32 core CPU with hyperthreading (i.e. 16 + 16). If you boot a 4 core guest and those cores are running on cores 0,1,16,17, then exposing CPU threads inside the guest best allows that OS to optimize for the case.

Now, whether this matters enough to keep doing is another matter, but I do think removing this outright would be a regression, based on the above.

> right so none of the host cpu tread sibling pairing was ever approved or allowed by the specs that intoduced cpu pinning and since the code im removing updated the cpu toptolgy in the numa toplogy not the one we used to generate the xml in inst.vcpu_model.topology i dont see how this could have ever had a practical impact on the guests.

It's a regression. It might well be an acceptable regression, but we were doing something before and no longer will be doing so afterwards. To be clear, I'm not arguing that we should keep this, but at a minimum we should be flagging this change in the release notes.

As I say that, I manage to reproduce this. I missed that you need to enable CPU pinning for this to happen. That makes sense since the vCPU processes of NUMA instances without a pinning policy will float across the whole NUMA node. I have provided a reproducer below. It will pass before this patch but fail after. This means things are working as I thought they would and we're breaking some optimization in doing this.

> i disagree 
> 
> the numa toplogy of the instance should have no baring on the virtual numa toplogy.

This isn't specific to NUMA. This is specific to CPU pinning. We're saying if a guest vCPU is pinned to two host cores and that those host cores are thread siblings, then we should expose this information to the guest for scheduling purposes.

With that said, this is relies on an awful lot going right. Chiefly, we'd have to make sure each host CPU thread sibling pair is correctly mapped to a guest VCPU thread sibling pair. The CPU topology of the guest has no bearing on the NUMA mapping, so we could easily end up doing things backwards. For example:

  host  0 -> 0 guest
        4 -> 1
        1 -> 2
        5 -> 3

so the host core thread sibling pairs are 0,4 and 1,5, but the guest has this backwards. I don't actually have a clue whether this is working as expected or how big the impact of removing things would be but I don't think we should be dismissing it out of hand.

i disagree 

the numa toplogy of the instance should have no baring on the virtual numa toplogy.

the root cause of this is the orginal aututhor of the vcpu toplogy work din not fully understand how numa would be added at the time they wrote this code.

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/juno/implemented/virt-driver-vcpu-topology.html

they assumed that we would map numa node to cpu sockets and a more fingrained vcpu toplogy

socket0:cores=2,threads=2,socket1:cores=4,threads=1 see https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/juno/implemented/virt-driver-vcpu-topology.html#alternatives

they implemented suppoort for generating thoes fine graded topologyes in the data models as part of 
https://github.com/openstack/nova/commit/770ab8eeb72b184ac6164aeabb89c4bf45f938a9 but that solution was ultimately rejected.

form the sepc 
"It is noted, however, that at time of writing, no virtualization technology provides any way to configure such asymmetrical topologies. Thus Nova is better served by ignoring this purely theoretical possibility and keeping its syntax simpler to match real-world capabilities that already exist."

and form the performance impact section we have 
"The cores vs sockets vs threads decision does not involve any scheduler interaction, since this design is not attempting to match host topology to guest topology. A later blueprint on CPU pinning will make it possible todo such host to guest topology matching, and its performance impact will be considered there."

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/juno/implemented/virt-driver-vcpu-topology.html#performance-impact

so the vitrual cpu toplogy featre has always been decupled form the host and guest numa toplogy.
i was part of the design and implementation of both the vcpu topology and numa toplogy feature
and how they would interact and this was one of the tenant we ensured in the design.


https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/VirtDriverGuestCPUMemoryPlacement tried to capture the larger picture 
and https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/juno/implemented/virt-driver-numa-placement.html
covers the introduction of numa.

we realist that modeling numa node as socket would not work long term so that corralation was broken in that spec as we also know it woudl have livemigation limitation as the virtual toplgoy cannot change while the guest is running.

its not that the removed code is no longer needed.
it was never correct to begin with and was written based on the incorrect assumetion that we could vary the cpu toplogy per numa nodes.

this is a common missunderstading that numa nodes and cpu socket are the same thing. they are not.
the auther assumed it was possible to have a different cpu toplogy per numa node but infact teh cpu toplgoy is vm wide and entirely independent form the virtual numa toplogy.

This is not the only case wehre those assumetion exits.
the data model that was created to model numa in nova allows use to constuct instance of the instatance_numa_toplogy object that cannot be requested form that api and that cannot be rendered into valid libvirt xml

specifying a different vcpu toplogy per numa node is an example of somethign that is not requestable via the api and not supporable in libvirt or any other hypervior.

we allso can model having different guest memroy pages size per numa node.
this is simiarly not requstable via the api but is actully supported by libvirt.

so in trying to be overly generic they made some assumtion that where invalid which is the root cause of the bug. they assume that if the vcpu toplogy requested per numa node was different they should then clamp the socket/cores/threads to the lowest value requests and then filters the toplogy to any value that was <= the clamped values.

this was never the correct thing to do and its that filtering that is the root cause of the bug so we jsut remve all of the invalid code.

i need to think about how to better capture that in the commit i guess but  that is why i just deleted the code.

> Users can't really do something, right?

Sure they can. They can start setting an explicit NUMA topology. I doubt anyone will do so because I doubt anyone was relying on this undocumented feature, but the option is there.

> Users even don't know about the nova releases, they only know about API microversions.
> If you *really* think we should signal something to users, this is not with a relnote but in general with a microversion. Of course, I'm not advocating about this here, so I tried to explain why we can't really say this is a upgrade note.

That's not true. There are different types of users. You're talking about end-users, but what about operators? We use 'Upgrade' relnotes to signal things like removed (not deprecated - actually removed) config options. The note serves as a warning to users than something has changed in this release and they might need to do something ahead of time. In this case, how we build our NUMA topology for guests has changed so we're calling that out. Some other examples of this type of release note:

- releasenotes/notes/remove-hooks-96d08645404d327c.yaml
- releasenotes/notes/remove-deprecated-libvirt-use_usb_tablet-opt-b01058905240b8ce.yaml
- releasenotes/notes/remove-nova-manage-db-null_instance_uuid_scan-f34494b316ff181c.yaml
- releasenotes/notes/require_port_binding_ext-e6d9bdd4f6eef4e3.yaml
- ...

> If you want, we could rather add some note in the prelude section after Xena-3 for explaining to the *operators* the behaviour change, but unless we wanna continue to support it by an config option, nothing more we can do here.

This isn't important enough IMO to warrant inclusion in the prelude section. However, even if it did, the prelude section usually summarizes the most critical changes that operators and end-users need to worry about, most of which will already have their own release note that will go into greater detail on the change. There are exceptions, such as calling out the max API microversion, but in general the prelude summarizes an already existing release note.

Tao - do you recall why this was necessary? Won't the start-stop-daemon in the stop() function terminate the children as well? I see that /etc/init.d/horizon uses stop-start-daemon and has child processes, yet does not have this extra step.
Yeah, there were rare cases that start-stop-daemon returned 0 but the processes were not killed. I suspected the processes were blocked on I/O in those cases.

maybe it can be rephrased to: "As an example, if a Service..."
calls the appropriate handler on the controller
which is watching for the Service object.
no need to specify the file name

in my view this is slightly different. The handlers are using the watcher to get notified when the specific type of object in K8s gets created/modified/deleted. So, rather than the watcher calling the handler, is the handler using the watcher to "watch" changes for a given object type on K8s side, and then trigger the needed actions. Thus, in the example, the ServiceHandler handler is using the watcher to detect changes on the K8s services and triggering the required "reconciliation" steps (between k8s resources and their needed OpenStack counterpart)
to detect the changes on them

README.rst.message: Where is this tag appearing from. I can not see it here? https://releases.openstack.org/train/index.html#train-tempest or even ussuri releases? How does one get this tempest commit id? Can you add some notes to this doc for clarity?
+1, i'm okay with saying "by default tempest will be installed from a commit specified in the "setup_env" script"

it comes from here:
https://opendev.org/osf/refstack-client/src/commit/7fbf6dad171cc7b4d61c908d6fc433cdefa67218/setup_env#L3-L4

It's a tempest commit we choose because it matched our criteria - as new as possible code (meaning that contains everything we need currently) but not that new it breaks older openstack releases we support running guidelines on. That commit is not tied to a tempest release, it's a commit which came after a 22.1.0 release. It can be viewed f.e. like this:
https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/e64c78dcf720202a0542bb1e1184f5229a11524f
or simply:
```
$ git clone https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest
$ cd tempest
$ git show e64c78dcf720202a0542bb1e1184f5229a11524f
```

I'm not sure what exactly I should put in the README regarding this commit - the commit is a fact, the user doesn't need to care why we have chosen that one and the usage of the commit goes to any git course.
should we use Manila as example instead of Zuul?

I don't follow, I pointed Zuul as an example, because in order to being able to chain not yet merged reviews of other projects together, the jobs in Zuul must use not the current master code of those projects but the master where new (not yet merged) reviews are cherry-picked on top of it.
F.e. refstack-client is in relation with python-tempestconf and in order to test new changes in python-tempestconf by Zuul jobs in refstack-client, the jobs must cherry-pick the new changes from python-tempestconf .. luckily that's what Zuul does for us - it automatically (when you put a depends-on in the commit msg) cherry-picks new changes. That's the when -s option of setup_env comes handy because it tells the script to use python-tempestconf from a specific location - the location where Zuul cloned master and cherry-picked new changes.

Therefore I put Zuul as an example - it is exactly the use case when -s option is very helpful.

afaik this is not how it should be done... I believe we should be using self.override_config instead

I think override_config would be better, but using it should probably be part of a larger refactoring of this file.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: But isn't our goal to allow other openinfra projects to join the interop effort and add their interoperability guidelines? The current working group is only OpenStack focussed (as far as I can tell), so without Board involvement, how do we drive the growth of the interop program across these openinfra projects?

The OpenStack Interop was created to support OpenStack Trademark program. How Trademark is handled for other OIF projects is not defined yet. Once it does Interop WG can consider if it can handle it. The current machinery, Tempest and Refstack are OpenStack specific. 
Board member can be elected as Interop WG chair. Nothing precludes it.
How? None of these people are part of the Board :) I understand one can passively participate in board meetings, but how can someone represent the board actively when being passive participants?

I will bring this up at OIF board June meeting. If board feels that they require a board member as a co-chair they can vote on it and we will modify the proposal. 
For now we need to make this change a part of the proposal and let OIF board to decide if they want to accept it. If it is not part of the proposal there is nothing for the board to consider.

tripleoclient/constants.py.message:
I'm not convinced having a default for these is the good approach.

It has been an issue that operators forget to include the file, run a deployment and we end up with a mess to fix.
We have check's to try to detect the missing environment/network-isolation.yaml and environment/network-environment.yaml in place to try to protect operators from doing this mistake today. If we add new defaults with network-v2, we need to implement similar checks again.

Would it not be better to make the '--networks-file' and '--vip-file' parameters mandatory? We can provide sample files for the default network-isolation scenario, and non-isolated scenarios. But force the operator to explicitly specify them.

Having them mandatory removes the 'forgot to include' from the equation.

If the deployment was top stop at validating the args, the breakage would'nt be very impactful? I mean, any deployed overcloud would'nt be affected. Worst case they'd need to update some automation and put it trough testing env before continuing with the update action with the '--networks-file <path_to_file' added to args? (For upgrades we do encurage testing the upgrade in a test env first, so operators would notice the change in a non-critical env)


Another option I've been thinking about is to update the defaults to look for the default in two places, in order:
 #1. Look in <work-dir>/<overcloud>/network_data.yaml
 #2. Look in <THT>/network_data.yaml if not found in #1.

We can make sure we put a copy in <work-dir>/<overcloud>/ whenever files are explicitly passed as args, so that the same input file is re-used on subsequent runs.

If we go with https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/791447, which place's the appropriate files as exported from the deployed stack into <work-dir>/<overcloud>/ during the undercloud upgrade step, so post upgrade the files with the correct content would be in the "first" default location.

WDYT? This may be something we should discuss on the mailing list or a spec?
I'm not sure if we can remove the default network_data.yaml as it would possibly be backward incompatibe and may break somebody (probably not production though).

We discussed this in the InteropWG meeting, but i'll state my views here for the general audience. 
What is "core" and what isn't has been a constant debate in the community. We used to have a project incubation process where new services would be accorded mature, core, TC approved and all the labels. However, this process was shut down many years ago. _WE_ in the InterOp working group shouldn't be the last gatekeepers of some archaic definition of "core" that might sound exclusionary to contributors of useful services that are all part of OpenStack. Neither the Open Infra Foundation nor the OpenStack TC have a concept of "core" projects. 

Maybe we should revise this definition a bit more. 

      OpenStack is a broad and diverse community with growing functionality.
      This growing functionality is achieved via "projects" which expose
      services to create Cloud Computing Platforms. This constant innovation is vital
      to OpenStack but separate from the definition of Core. The pursuit of this Interop effort
      is to define a stable platform that OpenStack functionality can be used to
      create. Not all services, and not all features are required to do that.
Done. But reworded it. Getting rid of word core all together.

I suggest diluting this a bit. Can we re-state along the lines of:

 The Interop effort is currently centered around three Platform programs:
 OpenStack Powered Platform, OpenStack Powered Compute and OpenStack Powered Storage.
 Each of these programs have designated sections of OpenStack components that
 form an important part of interoperability across implementations. Alongside
 these platforms, there are also "add-on" services that extend the functionality.
 OpenStack Powered Compute Platform encompasses designated sections from the
 OpenStack Identity (keystone), OpenStack Compute (nova), OpenStack Image Storage (glance),
 OpenStack Block Storage (cinder) and OpenStack Networking (neutron) services.

 The add-on guidelines include designated sections of the OpenStack DNS (designate), 
 OpenStack Orchestration (heat) and OpenStack Shared File System Storage (manila) services.
